coredata.dc:title: Simultaneously in-situ fabrication of lithium fluoride and sulfide enriched artificial solid electrolyte interface facilitates high stable lithium metal anode
coredata.dc:creator: Yang, Jian
Hou, Junming
Fang, Zixuan
Kashif, Khan
Chen, Cheng
Li, Xinran
Zhou, Haiping
Zhang, Shu
Feng, Tingting
Xu, Ziqiang
Wu, Mengqiang
coredata.dc:description: Lithium (Li) metal has to overcome key performance flaws before it can be used as the anode material for the next generation Li+ batteries. One of its major issues is Li dendrite growth and detachment, which causes safety issues and low Coulombic efficiency for Li metal batteries. Constructing a stable solid electrolyte interface (SEI) is considered to be the most straightforward solution to the Li anode interface defects. Here, we develop a facile stratagem of 2-(Fluorosulphonyl)difluoroacetic acid-treated Li foil to obtain a Li metal anode coated by the lithium fluoride and sulfide enriched composite layer (LiF/sulfide enriched Li). The experimental and theoretical simulations demonstrate that the ideal artificial SEI can induce uniform Li+ distribution at the interface and effectively inhibit dendrite growth. As results, the LiF/sulfide enriched Li symmetrical cells exhibit excellent cycling stability and low Li deposition overpotential, which maintain a low overpotential of ∼ 10 mV for over 1000 h at 1 mA cm−2 in an ether electrolyte of DME/DOL + LiTFSI and steadily cycles for 350 h in a carbonate electrolyte of EC/EMC + LiPF6. Furthermore, full cells assembled with NCM811 and sulfur cathode exhibit enhanced cyclability. This facile and controllable stratagem provides a more practical possibility for modifying the Li metal anode.

Artificial SEI
In-situ dendrite growth
Stable Li plating
Li metal anode

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Top-view SEM images of (a) pristine Li and (b) LiF/sulfide enriched Li. (c) O/Li, F, C, and S elemental mapping of LiF/sulfide enriched Li. (d) Optical images comparison of Li foil before and after the reaction. AFM topography image (e) and the corresponding Young modulus (E) map (f). (g-j) XPS at different etching depths from 0 to 18 nm of LiF/sulfide enriched Li, (g) atomic concentration of Li, F, and S, (h-j) high-resolution XPS spectra of F 1 s, S 2p, and Li 1 s.

Electrochemical performance of the Li||Li symmetrical cells with ether electrolyte (a-d and i-j) and carbonate electrolyte (e-h and k-l). (a and e) Initial Li deposition curves of LiF/sulfide enriched Li and pristine Li symmetrical cells, (b and f) Comparison of the cycling stability of the two symmetrical cells at a current density of 1 mA cm−2 and a fixed capacity of 1 mAh cm−2, (c and g) Rate performance of the two symmetrical cells at various current density after 1 h each of Li plating and stripping, (d and h) Average overpotential of the two cells varies with the current density. EIS profiles of symmetrical cells (i and k) LiF/sulfide enriched Li and (j and l) pristine Li.

Top-view SEM images of LiF/sulfide enriched Li and pristine Li after the number of a certain cycle of 1, 10, and 50 in carbonate and ether electrolyte. (a) LiF/sulfide enriched Li and (b) pristine Li in carbonate electrolyte, (c) LiF/sulfide enriched Li, and (d) pristine Li in ether electrolyte. Cross-section in-situ optical microscope images of LiF/sulfide enriched Li and pristine Li at the deposition time of (e-g) 0–50 min and (h) 0–20 min. (e) LiF/sulfide enriched Li and (f) pristine Li in ether electrolyte, (g) LiF/sulfide enriched Li, and (h) pristine Li in carbonate electrolyte.

Schematic illustration of Li deposition on (a) pristine Li and (b) LiF/sulfide enriched Li. Li nucleation and Li+ distribution at the interface of (c) pristine Li and (e) LiF/sulfide enriched Li. Current density distribution at the interface of (d) pristine Li and (f) LiF/sulfide enriched Li.

Electrochemical performance of the full cells. (a-c) Li||NCM811 full cell, (a) comparison of the initial charge/discharge curves, (b) comparison of long-term cycling behavior at 0.2C, (c) rate performance of the two types Li||NCM811 full cells at each current density. (d-f) Li||S full cell, (d) initial charge/discharge curves, (e) long-term cycling behavior at 0.5C. (f) rate performance of the Li||S full cells at each current density.

head.ce:title: Simultaneously in-situ fabrication of lithium fluoride and sulfide enriched artificial solid electrolyte interface facilitates high stable lithium metal anode

ce:footnote.ce:note-para: These authors contributed equally to this work.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The LiF/sulfide enriched artificial SEI can reduce the local current density and induce uniform Li+ distribution at the interface, realizing a stable and dendrites-free Li deposition on the surface of Li metal anodes.

Lithium (Li) metal has to overcome key performance flaws before it can be used as the anode material for the next generation Li+ batteries. One of its major issues is Li dendrite growth and detachment, which causes safety issues and low Coulombic efficiency for Li metal batteries. Constructing a stable solid electrolyte interface (SEI) is considered to be the most straightforward solution to the Li anode interface defects. Here, we develop a facile stratagem of 2-(Fluorosulphonyl)difluoroacetic acid-treated Li foil to obtain a Li metal anode coated by the lithium fluoride and sulfide enriched composite layer (LiF/sulfide enriched Li). The experimental and theoretical simulations demonstrate that the ideal artificial SEI can induce uniform Li+ distribution at the interface and effectively inhibit dendrite growth. As results, the LiF/sulfide enriched Li symmetrical cells exhibit excellent cycling stability and low Li deposition overpotential, which maintain a low overpotential of ∼ 10 mV for over 1000 h at 1 mA cm−2 in an ether electrolyte of DME/DOL + LiTFSI and steadily cycles for 350 h in a carbonate electrolyte of EC/EMC + LiPF6. Furthermore, full cells assembled with NCM811 and sulfur cathode exhibit enhanced cyclability. This facile and controllable stratagem provides a more practical possibility for modifying the Li metal anode.

ce:section.ce:para: Since the commercialization of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), tremendous progress has been made to increase energy density, reduce cost, and improve the performance of batteries [1,2]. However, there are big pitfalls behind the hot market for electric vehicles -- the near-limit energy density and poor safety performance of conventional power batteries [3,4]. At present, many approaches are being pursued in developing next-generation high-energy batteries, such as Li-oxygen and Li-sulfur batteries [5–8]. Among these approaches, it is undisputed that the Li metal anode can improve the energy density of high-energy batteries due to its ultra-high capacity of 3860 mAh g−1 and the most negative electrochemical potential of −3.04 V versus standard hydrogen electrode [9–11]. However, the issues of low Coulombic efficiency (CE) and poor safety reliability caused by Li dendrite must be overcome before the practical application of Li metal anode [12–14].

In recent years, several studies have been implemented to overcome these thorny issues of dendrite growth and side reactions, including alloying Li anode [15,16], using electrolyte additives [17,18], constructing 3-Dimensions electrode [19–21], modifying the surface of Li foil, etc. [22,23]. Constructing an artificial SEI on a Li metal surface is considered to be the simplest and most effective stratagem [24]. Plenty of efforts are made to fabricate robust artificial SEI film, such as adding film-forming additives (FEC [25], VC [26], and LiNO3 [27,28]) to build SEI film in-situ on the surface of Li foil. A further analysis of the composition of the artificial SEI reveals that LiF and other small molecule compounds of Li play a positive role in improving the ionic conductivity and structural stability of the artificial SEI [29]. This key conclusion paves a way for the construction of high-quality artificial SEI on Li metal surface.

At present, tremendous research interests have been focused on the construction of LiF layers on the surface of Li anode owing to its excellent mechanical strength [30–35]. For example, Lang et al. fabricated LiF-coated Li anodes in order to minimize the side reaction and hinder the dendrite formation [30]. Meanwhile, however, the high ion tunneling migration barrier of LiF also deteriorates the diffusion kinetics of Li+ through the SEI, leading to the low Li+ conductivity of SEI [36]. Therefore, it is significant to improve the Li+ conductivity of LiF-enriched SEI without worsening the mechanical strength, and the introduction of small-molecule compounds containing Li is an effective solution to reduce the high ion migration barrier of the artificial SEI. Recently, excellent Li deposition performance can be obtained by constructing LiF-based artificial SEI, such as LiF/Li-Al [22], LiF/Li3Sb [34], LiF/Li7Sn3 [37], LiF/h-BN [38], LiF-Li3N-Li2S [39] et. al. Although, these works have modified the Li metal anode to a certain extent, the effect of the LiF-rich composite small molecule artificial SEI layer on the Li anode remains to be further studied. It is meaningful to further explore the performance of LiF composites layer coated Li metal anode by a practical and efficient stratagem.

In this work, we designed and constructed a Li metal anode rich in LiF/sulfide composite artificial SEI and thus improved the uniformity of Li deposition. The dense LiF/sulfide enriched protective layer can effectively reduce the side reactions between Li and electrolyte, induce the uniform distribution of Li+ at the interface, and achieve uniform Li deposition. The symmetrical cells are assembled with ether electrolyte (DME/DOL + LiTFSI) and carbonate electrolyte (EC/EMC + LiPF6), and both of them show a stable and dendrite-free Li deposition process. The experimental and theoretical simulations show that the LiF/sulfide artificial SEI can reduce the local current density at the electrode interface, realizing a stable Li deposition process. When paired with a typical NCM811 and sulfur cathode, the assembled LiF/sulfide enriched Li||NCM811 and LiF/sulfide enriched Li||S full cells exhibit improved capability and stable cycling performance. This research serves to guide material design in achieving Li anode materials which do not suffer from dendrite formation.

10 mL of 2-(Fluorosulphonyl)difluoroacetic acid (FDA) solution (Sigma, CAS: 680–15-9) was poured into a cleaned glass bottle. Place the pristine Li foil (450 μm or 80 μm) in the solution and shake it until fully soaked, static for different times (the default reaction time is 5 min for LiF/sulfide enriched Li without time described in this article). Then, pick out the treated Li foil and remove the residual solvent with an absorbent filter paper. The as-prepared LiF/sulfide enriched Li was be used for subsequent characterization.

X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) analysis was conducted using a Thermo Scientific K-α instrument with an Mg anode (monochromatic Kα X-rays at 1253.6 eV) as the source in an Ar-filled glove box. Ar etching was applied to check the chemical state of the sample under different depths. The rate of etching standard samples is about 0.29 nm/s. A field-emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, JSM-5900LV, JEOL) was used to characterize the microscopic surface morphology of the as-prepared films and lithium anode electrodes. Elemental composition was analyzed using energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) with the same FE-SEM instrument. Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM) imaging and force spectroscopy experiments were performed on CyPer ES with inert atmosphere protection. In-situ optical microscopy was conducted with a high-definition digital electronic measurement microscope that was equipped with a mold from Beijing Scistar Technology Co., LTD. Tests were conducted at a current density of 0.5 mA cm−2.

For symmetrical cells, two LiF/sulfide enriched Li or pristine Li foils with a diameter of 10 mm were assembled with CR2032 coin-type cells in an Ar-filled glove box with O2 and H2O content below 0.1 ppm. The polypropylene film (Celgard 2400) was employed as the separator. 40 μL carbonate electrolyte (1.0 M LiPF6 in EC/EMC (3:7, by volume)) and ether electrolyte (1.0 M LiTFSI in DOL/DME (1:1, by volume) with 1% LiNO3) was employed as the electrolyte.

For assembling Li||NCM811 full cells, NCM811 (Tianjin B&M science and technology Co., Ltd.) served as the cathode, with Celgard 2400 soaked in 40 μL carbonate electrolyte (1 M LiPF6 EC/EMC 3:7 v/v) as the separator. The mass loading of NCM811 cathodes is about 3 mg cm−2. For Li||S full cells, the sulfur powder was mixed with Super-P (purchased from Guangdong Canrd New Energy Technology Co., Ltd. (CAS: 1333–86-4)) at a mass ratio of 2 to 1, and then sintered in an inert atmosphere at 155℃ for 12 h. Subsequently, calcinated at 300 ℃ for 2 h to obtained sulfur/carbon (S/C) cathode. 80 wt% sulfur/carbon, 10 wt% acetylene black, and 10 wt% polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) binder in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) solvent to prepared sulfur/carbon electrode. The sulfur content of the S/C cathode is controlled to be 70 wt% (the mass loading of sulfur is about 5 mg cm−2). Celgard 2400 was chosen as separator and the electrolytes were 1.0 M LiTFSI-DOL/DME (1:1 in volume) with 1 wt% LiNO3 as additive. All cells were tested on a LAND battery test system (CT2001A) at room temperature. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) data were collected with a PARSTAT 4000 A electrochemical workstation over a frequency range of 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz.

The morphology of pristine Li and LiF/sulfide enriched Li electrode is shown in a top-view scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image (Fig. 1 a and b), respectively. SEM comparisons at different magnifications are provided in Fig. S1 (Supporting information). The surface of the pristine Li is smooth. After being treated with FDA solution, a uniform and dense surface with a porous structure were obtained. The uniform elements (Li/O, F, C, and S) distribution can be confirmed by energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) elemental mapping in Fig. S2a. The cross-section image of LiF/sulfide enriched Li clearly shows the LiF/sulfide enriched layer with a thickness of about 50 μm (Fig. 1c). The EDX mapping corresponding to the LiF/sulfide enriched Li cross-section shows the regional element distribution of the LiF/sulfide enriched layer and the Li metal layer (Fig. S2b). The changes of Li foil before, during, and after the reaction can be observed through the optical images in Fig. 1d. With the increase of reaction time, the color of the Li foil gradually darkens. The resulting LiF and sulfide compounds cover the surface of the Li foil compactly. AFM topography image and the corresponding Young modulus (E) map are given in Fig. 1e and f, the average value of Young's modulus is 32.923 GPa (the young's modulus of pure Li is only 4.9 GPa). This can reflect that the LiF/sulfide enriched layer has strong mechanical properties.

To further confirm the element on the surface of Li metal, we employ the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements of different etching depths to analyze the element content and valence on the surface of LiF/sulfide-enriched Li. As shown in Fig. S3a, the peaks of Li 1 s, S 2p, C 1 s, O 1 s, and F1s can be found in the full XPS spectrum within the surface depth of 18 nm. The element's contents of Li, F, and S are provided in Fig. 1g. With the increase of etching depth, the contents of Li and F increased from 25.41 to 33.12 atomic% and from 14.17 to 16.71 atomic%, respectively, while the contents of sulfur decreased slightly (from 7.13 to 5.7 atomic%). In general, there is no significant difference in the element content at different depths, which indicates that the elements and components of the artificial SEI protective layer are evenly distributed. Fig. 1h shows high-resolution XPS spectra of the F 1 s at the depth of 0, 9, and 18 nm, LiF can be observed at 684.5 eV, and -C-Fx from the organic constituents is observed at 687 and 689.5 eV [10,40]. The composition of the artificial SEI protective layer is further probed by taking the S 2p XPS spectra from the surface etched by argon sputtering (Fig. 1i). It is clear that moderate amounts of sulfonate, sulfinate, and sulfate salts (organic components containing sulfur) can be detected from the treated surface with etching depths of 9 and 18 nm [33,41]. As compared to the untreated samples, the peak at 163 eV of the etched samples, which represents the Li-Sx, can be detected, and this difference may be caused by the instability of Li-Sx on the surface. In the Li 1 s spectra (Fig. 1l), the peak at 54.4 eV corresponds to Li-O-R (R corresponds to H or organic constituents), and the peaks at 55.3 and 56.2 eV correspond to LiF and sulfide containing Li, respectively [23]. The C-O, C = O, and Li-O-R bonds can be found by C 1 s and O 1 s spectra of the LiF/sulfide enriched layer in Fig. S3b and 3c.

The reaction time was controlled to obtain artificial SEI with different thicknesses and compared their electrochemical performance. As shown in Fig. S4, the samples treated for 5 mins shows the best stability and the lowest Li deposition overpotential in both ester and ether electrolytes. To compare the nucleation overpotential between the LiF/sulfide enriched Li and pristine Li on the first cycling, two kinds of symmetrical cells are assembled with ether electrolyte (DME/DOL + LiTFSI) and carbonate electrolyte (EC/EMC + LiPF6) for the test. The initial nucleation overpotential and curves are given in Fig. 2 a (ether electrolyte) and Fig. 2e (carbonate electrolyte). For the Li||Li symmetrical cell with ether electrolyte, the plating voltage of pristine Li starts at a more negative value (-137.6 mV), then slightly rises and stabilizes at ∼ -65 mV thereafter cycling. In comparison, the LiF/sulfide enriched Li shows a low overpotential of −13 ∼ -15 mV at the whole Li deposition process. For the Li||Li symmetrical cell with carbonate electrolyte, the LiF/sulfide enriched Li also shows a more stable and lower voltage change, which corresponds to the formation of SEI on the electrode surface in the initial stage. It also indicates that a lower Li deposition barrier is established on the surface of LiF/sulfide enriched Li, and it becomes easier and more stable for Li+ to plate and strip from LiF/sulfide enriched Li in both systems in comparison to both systems without constructing artificial SEI [42].

After the first circle, we also evaluate the long-term cyclic stability of symmetrical cells with two types of electrolytes, which are performed at 1 mA cm−2 and a fixed area capacity of 1 mAh cm−2. In Fig. 2b, the LiF/sulfide enriched Li symmetrical cell with ether electrolyte shows long-term stability of 1200 h and a low overpotential of ∼ 10 mV. In contrast, the pristine Li symmetrical cell can only cycle stably for 300 h, and then show a large voltage increase. The details of voltage profiles at different cycle times are provided in Fig. S5. For the cyclic performance of symmetrical cells assembled with carbonate electrolyte (Fig. 2f), the LiF/sulfide enriched Li displays smooth plating/stripping evolution curves with a gradual and small increase in overpotential, and it maintains a low value during the cycling process. In contrast, the voltage of long cycle life increases obviously and fluctuates dramatically in the charge/discharge process, which reflects an unstable interface process. The cycling performance of the cells assembled with ether and carbonate electrolytes at higher current and capacity is given in Fig. S6, and the LiF/sulfide enriched Li both exhibit superior cycle stability and lower overpotential over the pristine Li.

In order to further evaluate the stability of the LiF/sulfide enriched Li, the rate performance of the two types of symmetrical cells are carried out under current densities of 0.5 to 4 mA cm−2 after 1 h each of Li plating and stripping (Fig. 2c and 2 g). For the symmetrical cells assembled with ether electrolyte (Fig. 2c), the voltage curve of the LiF/sulfide enriched Li is found to be more stable, and the overpotential is lower than that of pristine Li. For the pristine Li symmetrical cell, the short circuit appears at 3 mA cm−2, while the LiF/sulfide enriched Li shows a stable cycle state during the whole process. Furthermore, the average overpotential of the LiF/sulfide enriched Li symmetrical cells is almost linearly related to the current density (Fig. 2d). The same rule applies to symmetrical cells assembled using carbonate electrolytes (Fig. 2g). The overpotential of the LiF/sulfide enriched Li symmetrical cell remains stable at different current densities and area capacity from 1 mA cm−2 to 4 mA cm−2. In comparison, the blank symmetrical cells show large fluctuations in overpotential when the current density reaches 3 mA cm−2. The Li plating curve is asymmetrical to the stripping one, which reflects the poor consistency of the electrode surface reaction in the blank cells. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 2h, the average overpotential of LiF/sulfide enriched Li symmetrical cell at given current densities is far less than that of a blank cell. This further indicates the good reversibility on the surface of LiF/sulfide enriched Li. The performance comparison of the Li||Cu asymmetrical cells is provided in Fig. S7. The LiF/sulfide enriched Li||Cu cells show exhibit higher CE and cycle stability in both ester and ether electrolytes.

Fig. 2i-l shows the electrochemical impedance spectroscopies (EIS) of the two types Li||Li symmetrical cells with ether electrolyte and carbonate electrolyte before and after various cycles (0th, 1st, 10th, and 50th) at 1 mA cm−2 for 1 h. The two arcs associated with charge-transfer resistance (
R
c t
) and SEI resistance (
R
S E I
) are observed [43]. In the symmetrical cell with ether electrolyte (Fig. 2i and j), the
R
c t
of both the LiF/sulfide enriched Li and pristine Li decreased significantly as the cycling time. It is obvious that the
R
c t
of LiF/sulfide enriched Li symmetrical cell is much smaller than that of pristine Li symmetrical cell after the same cycling number.
R
S E I
is almost not observed in pristine Li symmetrical cells before and after the 1st cycle (a significant
R
S E I
is observed after the 10th cycle), and this may be the reason that the SEI is not formed at the initial stage. In contrast, the LiF/sulfide enriched Li symmetrical cell has a small
R
S E I
of ∼ 10 Ω before the cycle, and the
R
S E I
increases to ∼ 20 Ω after the 1st cycle, then gradually decreases as the cycles number increase. The mature
R
S E I
of LiF/sulfide enriched Li symmetrical cell is lower than that of pristine Li symmetrical cell. As for the symmetrical cells with carbonate electrolyte (Fig. 2k and l), the
R
c t
and
R
S E I
decrease with an increasing cycling number, while the LiF/sulfide enriched Li symmetrical cells show a smaller
R
c t
and
R
S E I
than that of pristine Li symmetrical cells. During cycling, the small
R
c t
and
R
S E I
are the key to stabilize Li plating/stripping process, which can improve the ability of Li+ transportation and reduce the deposition of dendritic Li on the anode surface.

In order to study the morphological evolution of LiF/sulfide enriched Li and pristine Li with increasing cycles number, the SEM images of the electrodes after cycling for 1, 10, and 50 times at 1 mA cm−2 and 1 mAh cm−2 (the last discharge is taken as the cut-off condition) is given in Fig. 3 . Fig. 3a, 3b, and S8 show the morphology of LiF/sulfide enriched electrode and pristine Li electrode in carbonate electrolyte. After an initial Li deposition, Li is uniformly distributed on the surface of the LiF/sulfide enriched electrode, and there are no Li dendrites on its surface even the cycle period is further extended to 10 and 50. The cross-section SEM images of the LiF/sulfide enriched Li after cycling for 1, 10, and 50 times are shown in Fig. S9d-f. From the first cycle to the 10th cycle, the structural changes of the LiF/sulfide enriched layer are almost invisible. After 50 cycles, the artificial SEI layer is still clearly visible. For the pristine Li electrode (Fig. 3b and S8d-f), a large heterogeneous Li nucleation can be found in the first deposition. The rod-like dendrites and large bulges are observed on the surface of the electrodes after 10 and 50 cycles. This demonstrates that LiF/sulfide enriched protective layer contributes to the uniform Li deposition in carbonate electrolytes. The surface morphology evolution of the two types of Li electrodes in ether electrolyte is given in Fig. 3c, d, and S10. After the first Li deposition, Li is smoothly distributed on the surface of the LiF/sulfide enriched electrode without discernible bulges. After further extending to 10 and 50 cycles, the electrode still shows uniform Li deposition without the formation of evident Li dendrites and dead Li. The corresponding cross-section images in Fig. S9a-c showed that the LiF/sulfide enriched layer can withstand the test of multiple cycles. In comparison, the pristine Li shows a large number of rod-like dendrites and dead Li (Fig. 3d and S10d-f). The surface evenness gradually deteriorated with the increasing cycling number. This further confirms that the uniform LiF/sulfide enriched artificial SEI promotes uniform Li deposition.

In-situ optical microscopy is used to directly and visually monitor the deposition behavior of Li on the electrodes. As shown in Fig. 3e (ether electrolyte), the images are sampled at the deposition time of 0, 10, 20, 30, 40, and 50 mins respectively. Metallographic luster can be observed gradually at the interface, indicating that fresh Li is evenly plated on the surface of the LiF/sulfide enriched electrode. In comparison, Li dendrites start to grow on the surface of the pristine Li electrode after 10 min, and gradually increase with deposition time (Fig. 3f). For the symmetrical cells with carbonate electrolytes, no dendrites can be observed on the LiF/sulfide enriched Li surface under the deposition time from 1 min to 50 mins (Fig. 3g). However, dendrites and bubbles appear on the surface of pristine Li in a short time (Fig. 3h); this finding indicates that the non-uniform Li deposition of pristine Li in ester electrolyte is accompanied by violent side reactions. The dendrites grow rapidly and are almost in contact with the counter electrode at 20 min. Fig. S11 provides the optical images of LiF/sulfide enriched Li and pristine Li in different electrolytes completing the initial plating/stripping process. The two electrodes of the LiF/sulfide enriched Li symmetrical cell show a uniform Li deposition in both ether and carbonate electrolytes. However, dendrites can be observed on both electrodes in the symmetrical cell assembled with pristine Li. This intuitive result further illustrates that LiF/sulfide enriched protective layer contributes to the uniform Li deposition in both ether and carbonate electrolytes.

The schematic diagram of Li deposition on the surface of pristine Li and LiF/sulfide enriched Li is shown in Fig. 4 a and b. Based on the conclusions mentioned above, non-uniform Li deposition occurs on the surface of the pristine Li, resulting in the formation of Li dendrites or even the dead Li as the cycle goes on. Due to the optimized Li+ distribution at the interface by LiF/sulfide enriched protective layer, LiF/sulfide enriched Li anode exhibits harmonious Li deposition without dendrite. In addition, LiF/sulfide enriched protective layer reduces the nucleation overpotential and the side-reactions, which plays a positive role in the interfacial Li conduction and transformation.

To further reveal the critical roles of LiF/sulfide enriched artificial SEI in Li deposition process, the COMSOL Multiphysics software, coupling with “Tertiary Current Distribution, Nernst-Planck” physics module, are employed for the Finite element simulation. The key experimental parameters required for theoretical simulation are provided in Supporting information . As shown in Fig. 4c, Li+ at the interface is unevenly distributed on the surface of pristine Li. To be precise, Li+ tends to concentrate around the Li nucleus. In the Li deposition process, the deposition rate in this region becomes faster, leading to the formation of dendrites. We simulate the current density at the electrode interface and find that the current density near the heterogeneous nucleation is higher than that in other regions (Fig. 4d), directly leading to the dendrite growth. In contrast, the artificial SEI homogenizes the distribution of Li+ at the electrode interface (Fig. 4e), and the deposition current density in the selected region is the same everywhere (Fig. 4f). Dynamic models of Li deposition on the electrode surface of LiF/sulfide enriched Li and pristine Li are provided in the Supplementary information (gif-S1 and gif-S2). This further proves the experimental conclusion of uniform Li deposition at LiF/sulfide enriched Li metal anode.

In order to evaluate the practical application of the obtained LiF/sulfide enriched based dendrite-free Li anode, Li||NCM811 full cells are assembled with carbonate electrolyte. Fig. 5 a shows the initial charge/discharge curves of the pristine Li and LiF/sulfide enriched Li with NCM811 cathode-based full cells at 0.2C. The initial charge capacity of pristine Li||NCM811 full cell is 257.7 mAh g−1, but the initial discharge capacity is only 182.5 mAh g−1, corresponding to a low initial CE of 70.8%. In contrast, the initial charge and discharge capacity of LiF/sulfide enriched Li||NCM811 full cell is 236 and 196.72 mAh g−1, respectively (initial CE up to 84%). The long-term cycling behavior of the two types Li||NCM811 full cells at a current density of 0.2C are shown in Fig. 5b. In the first 90 cycles, the two cells show similar stability, but the LiF/sulfide enriched Li||NCM811 full cell has a slightly high specific capacity. After 90 cycles, the CEs and discharge capacity of pristine Li||NCM811 full cell decreases sharply, but LiF/sulfide enriched Li||NCM811 full cell can steadily cycle up to 200 times. As shown in Fig. 5c, the excellent reversible charge/discharge capacities both at low and high rates are successfully obtained for LiF/sulfide enriched Li||NCM811 full cell. Especially, the LiF/sulfide enriched Li||NCM811 full cell has an obvious advantage over the pristine Li||NCM811 full cell at high rates of 2 and 5C. The Li||S full cells are also assembled to evaluate the practical application of LiF/sulfide enriched Li in ether electrolytes. In Fig. 5d, the initial CE of LiF/sulfide enriched Li||S full cell is as high as 95%, whereas the initial CE of pristine Li||S full cell is only 84%. In addition, LiF/sulfide enriched Li||S full cell shows a lower overpotential between charge and discharge curves. The cycling performance and CEs comparison at 0.5C are given in Fig. 5e, and LiF/sulfide enriched Li||S full cell has both high charge–discharge specific capacity and high CE. The LiF/sulfide enriched Li||S full cell exhibits a better rate performance in comparison to pristine Li||S full cell in Fig. 5f. Similar to Li||NCM811 full cell, the performance advantage of LiF/sulfide enriched Li||S full cell is more outstanding at a high rate. All these results demonstrated that LiF/sulfide enriched artificial SEI can significantly homogenize the plating/stripping behavior of Li, and it plays a very important role in improving the cycle stability and CE of the full cell. In order to further evaluate the practicability of the experimental scheme reported in this work, we carried out the same modification treatment on 80 μm Li foil (treated for 2 mins). The cycling performance comparison of Li||NCM811 at 0.5C is shown in Fig. S12, which further demonstrates that the experimental scheme can be further applied.

In summary, a rationally designed LiF/sulfide enriched artificial SEI is employed as an efficient regulator for homogenizing Li deposition. It is further proved theoretically and experimentally that the LiF/sulfide enriched artificial SEI homogenizes the Li+ distribution and current density at the interface. The obtained LiF/sulfide enriched Li anode shows excellent cycling stability and low Li deposition overpotential in both carbonate and ether electrolytes. The as-assembled Li||NCM811 and Li||S full cells are further verified the ideal application potential of LiF/sulfide enriched Li anode. The facile and effective stratagem reported in this study provides a possible solution to the critical problem of Li metal anode.
